/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thank you for the feedback. I agree our issue should be solved by removing the pragma from the devstack configuration. But since this can always happen to a third party system, it seems important to enable excluding pragma. I think that should be the default as I don't see a use for pragma outside of integrated system

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> I'm not sure what you are suggesting should be the default.  Are you saying that Zuul should never include pragma?  It's proven to be absolutely critical in OpenStack.  I caution you not to make that evaluation based on this one instance where I've clearly established the feature is being used incorrectly.
> 

I'm saying that third party Zuul, when importing job, should not include the pragma. If I understand correctly, the current behavior makes the branch matcher unable to work with foreign branch.

Perhaps this is not the intended behavior and there is a bug somewhere else. But right now it does not seems possible to use the devstack job in a branch named `foo`, the scheduler simply skip the job (and it does not provide any feedback beside the `did not match` scheduler debug log).

> I suspect there is an actual bug with branch matchers here that is affecting both you and the devstack project, but all of this work is just papering over it.
> 
> I still don't actually understand why the pragma is causing a problem here.  You say that the problem is that Zuul sees:
> 
> Variant <Job devstack branches: {MatchAny:{ImpliedBranchMatcher:master},{ImpliedBranchMatcher:feature/r1}} source: openstack/devstack/.zuul.yaml@master#437> did not match
> 
> But if you remove the pragma, you're going to end up with:
> 
> Variant <Job devstack branches: {MatchAny:{ImpliedBranchMatcher:master}} source: openstack/devstack/.zuul.yaml@master#437> did not match
> 
> Because it's still going to have an implied branch matcher.
> 
> I'm starting to think the pragma is a red herring, and you need to look into why override-checkout isn't causing the devstack job to match the branch you want.

I believe the pragma is the source of the problem, excluding it makes the branch matcher respect the override-checkout. If this is a bug, would you know where to look for fixing it?

Here are poc using override-checkout for the tests.unit.test_v3.TestIncludePragma.test_pragma_include:

https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/814842 with the pragma fails with `Variant <Job job branches: {MatchAny:{ImpliedBranchMatcher:feature/r1}} source: common-jobs/zuul.yaml@master#5> did not match <Change 0x7f260c1a9190 org/project 1,1>`

https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/814843 without the pragma succeeds with `Variant <Job job branches: {MatchAny:{ImpliedBranchMatcher:master}} source: common-jobs/zuul.yaml@master#1> matched <Change 0x7f4e4450e310 org/project 1,1>`

tests/fixtures/config/pragma-include/mai.message: oops, pipeline should not be included, it's actually not possible to include pipeline from untrusted-projects.

zuul/releasenotes/notes/load-pragma-fd26.message:
I may hove not been clear.  Here is an example of how the branch matcher pragma was intended to be used:

OpenStack Cinder interacts with Ceph.  They both have branch codenames based on their release.

The cinder stable/pike branch is designed to work with the ceph stable/jewel branch.  In that case, the cinder project should add the pragma:

implied-branches:
 - stable/pike
 - stable/jewel

No matter what system you load cinder into, the stable/pike branch of cinder is designed to work with the stable/jewel branch of ceph.

I would think we should always include it unless there's some special reason not to.  It's a project's way of saying "This project has only one branch that matters" (implied-branch-matchers: false), or "Branch foo on this project is the same as branch bar elsewhere" (implied-branches: [foo, bar]).

Generally speaking, I would expect both of those to be true no matter what system the repo was loaded into.

I just looked at the devstack project to see what it's pragma was, and I see that it's the thing gtema set up for the feature branch.  I don't think that is the right way to use pragmas or the right way to solve that problem.

I'm starting to think that the best solution to your issue might be to remove the pragma from devstack.

This is the thing that concerns me a bit.  We apparently thought pragma was special enough we should always obey it.  But I agree you have found a situation where you don't want it.  And basically anyone with a tenant config with 'include' will need to make a change in order to keep the status quo.

What we have now "include: ['job']" is so simple, straightforward, and intuitive, and 'pragma' is such a weird and advanced concept, I sort of hesitate to suggest that everyone should need to remember to "include" pragma in order for jobs to work as intended.

If we keep the change as-is, we should probably at least split it into two in order to let people add pragma as a no-op now, then make the actual change shortly afterwords.

But I wonder if, instead, we could do something like make pragma "exclude only".  Like, it's always included unless you add an exclude line.  So if I remember your case correctly, it would be:
  include: job
  exclude: pragma

Maybe that would be a reasonable compromise between having the ability to disable it, but having things work as expected/designed by default?
That would work, but I wonder in which situation do we actually want to include the pragma?
I don't think such pragma ("branch bar elsewhere") should matter for third party systems, e.g.  foreign zuul gated repositories should be able to have their own branch names.

How a project's branch named `foo` designed to work with `pike` is supposed to use the cinder job? Should it be added to the implied-branches pragma, or does it have to use custom override-checkout for both ceph and cinder?

Thanks for the quick change.

I'd guess it's a safe assumption (?) that any hardware older than Nehalem is not capable of running OpenStack.  I can confirm this much:

With 

import uuid
import netaddr
....
The error is:
./neutron_lib/api/converters.py:14:1: H306: imports not in alphabetical order (uuid, netaddr)
import netaddr

I added this empty line intentionally. Otherwise pep8 check is failing.

import netaddr
import uuid

import uuid
import netaddr

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
If the relatively small survey of systems available in our labs has run into some BIOS which either don't set MMIO resources or don't size them correctly then it is highly probable that the broader STX community will run into this as well, given the diversity of equipment STX will be run on. I suspect using quirks would not be broad enough either.

In order to ensure most machines will be able to work around BIOS issues I believe configuring the kernel with PCI_REALLOC_ENABLE_AUTO is needed and 100% necessary. Most Linux distros have made similar determinations, making this something that can be tuned without having to rebuild the kernel.

In a similar vein setting pci=realloc is also safe and the correct default. Per the documentation "if allocations done by BIOS are too small", *if*, so if the BIOS is setup correctly no action is taken. So once again this will ensure STX will boot on the widest variety of systems out of the box.
Thanks Mark.  So Jiping, go ahead and turn on the config option and let's be done with this.
We also can enable CONFIG_PCI_REALLOC_ENABLE_AUTO=y that also will realloc PCI source.  that is similar with bootargs pci=realloc.

Got it, I will abandon this one.  submit config in kernel git.

That is better than the bootarg in my opinion.  But, if I recall correctly, as Vefa has pointed out, if it is just a particular platform with a broken bios causing this issue, you might be able to code a pci quirk for that.  We have a patch already along those lines you could look at.

networking/iproute/centos/meta_patches/i.message: Uh, am I missing something?  You say that we are modifying this package, yet I don't see any other patches beyond this one.  No need at all to build a package if we aren't changing it, just use the binary pre-built package.

Hello Jim,

I can confirm that there is an incompatibility due to the versions of the C library included in CentOS 7 and CentOS 8. In the shell interaction snippet below, I downloaded iproute's CentOS 8.4.2105 RPM, and attempted to install it onto a StarlingX (master branch version) virtual machine I had running:

```
controller-0:~# rpm --test -Uvh iproute-5.9.0-4.el8.x86_64.rpm 
warning: iproute-5.9.0-4.el8.x86_64.rpm: Header V3 RSA/SHA256 Signature, key ID 8483c65d: NOKEY
error: Failed dependencies:
        libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.27)(64bit) is needed by iproute-5.9.0-4.el8.x86_64

controller-0:~# rpm -q -f /lib64/libc.so.6 
glibc-2.17-317.el7.x86_64
```

The key verification error can be ignored for this exercise, but CentOS 8.4.2105 appears to ship with glibc 2.27, whereas CentOS 7 ships with glibc 2.17.

Hello Jim, the source package is imported from CentOS 8.4.2105, which, as far as I know, is most likely not (API/ABI) compatible with CentOS 7 due to different shared library versions. Perhaps I misunderstood you though. Could you elaborate?

Good, capture the fact in the commit header that we can't use the prebuilt due to it requiring glibc 2.27 vs the 2.17 that we use, so we must rebuild it even though we haven't changed it.

And remove ", to make it clear that the iproute package has been
modified downstream by StarlingX." from the patch's commit log since we haven't actually modified anything.
The package dependencies encoded in the rpm when you load it, or even when you build the iso should catch that, if there truly are any incompatibilities.

why does a IPv6 address need to be enclosed in []?

Because IPv6 addresses contain colons, and URLs use colons to separate the host from the port number, RFC2732 specifies that an IPv6 address used as the host-part of a URL should be enclosed in square brackets, e.g. scheme://[2001:db8:4006:812::200e] or scheme://[2001:db8:4006:812::200e]:8080/path/page.html.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Actually this patch is introducing a security vulnerability. Any egress/ingress traffic handled by the iptables FW should not be override by something like you propose. If the traffic you need to introduce in this VM does not match the SG rules created, add new ones.

If those SG rules are not valid, maybe use allowed-address-pairs. And if this is not enough, disable port security for a specific port.

But I don't recommend a feature like this.

Thanks for taking a look at this! The specific problem we are facing is that we have routed traffic to a VM incoming via a Layer3 VXLAN interface. When this traffic hits iptables, the PHYSDEV-IN is the VXLAN interface, not the TAP interface for the VM. Therefore, none of the iptables rules created by neutron are matched, and the traffic is accepted. Ideally, we want this routed traffic to the VM to use the same iptables chains as bridged traffic. Rather than duplicating all of the rules, and changing PHYSDEV-IN to be the VXLAN interface instead of the TAP interface, it seems more efficient to simply redirect traffic to the existing chains.

The 2.7 ansible doc does not include the option for relative time. This relative time is added in 2.9 ansible doc.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.7/modules/openssl_certificate_module.html

selfsigned_not_after - "The timestamp at which the certificate stops being valid. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME. If this value is not specified, certificate will stop being valid 10 years from now.

Compare 2.9:
selfsigned_not_after - "default "+3650d... The point in time at which the certificate stops being valid.
Time can be specified either as relative time or as absolute timestamp."

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.9/modules/openssl_certificate_module.html

2021-10-08T23:58:06.580 Error: 2021-10-08 23:58:05 +0000 /Stage[main]/Platform::Etcd::Upgrade::Runtime/File[/etc/kubernetes/pki/apiserver-etcd-client.crt]: Could not evaluate: Could not retrieve information from environment production source(s) file:/var/run/platform/config/21.12/etcd/apiserver-etcd-client.crt

Maybe there is no apiserver-etcd-client.key in runtime folder
I guest we need to put apiserver-etcd-client.key *.crt into "{{ config_permdir + '/etcd' }}/{{ item }}"

kernel-std/centos/patches/0010-bpf-cgrou.message: How is it that this commit ID doesn't match the one you cite above your SOB line? If you did a 'git format patch' this should match. I am more curious than concerned.

Ah yes, and of course reapplying with your SOB line will have resulted in a different ID at the top. Thanks, this makes sense and is of course why we want to capture the 'real' commit ID in the commit log as you have.

My procedure was as follows: I ran "git cherry-pick -x 8520e224f547cd070c7c8f97b1fc6d58cff7ccaa" in my local copy of the linux-yocto-std kernel tree, but with all of the previous StarlingX 9 patches already applied. I had to apply two minor fix-ups to resolve merge conflicts, and I then ran "git add -u && git cherry-pick --continue", followed by "git format-patch -N -o . --start-number=10 -1 HEAD".

All of these operations are expected to result in a different commit ID, as I could not use "git format-patch -N -o . --start-number=10 -1 8520e224f547cd070c7c8f97b1fc6d58cff7ccaa" due to the merge conflicts.

Perhaps this was an issue though: I did not mention what I had to change for making the patch apply. Here is a brief explanation:

* The long comment block that is replaced by this patch had gone through a few typo fixing commits, which is why I had a merge conflict.
* More importantly, in the baseline for the cherry-picked commit, the second argument of "sock_from_file" (named "err", for storing errors) was removed, as err is only set to non-zero in "sock_from_file" when that function is about to return NULL. I adapted the patch to v5.10 based on this information.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This is what the log looks like when it triggers the evacuations
The first log is what we always see (a warning)  and the second is our override

2021-10-21T16:08:19.483 controller-0                           VIM_Thread[1151]    DEBUG                     _instance_task_work.py.699   Evacuate-Instance for nova_server-2703, but host controller-1 is not offline or power-off.
2021-10-21T16:08:19.484 controller-0                           VIM_Thread[1151]    DEBUG                     _instance_task_work.py.706   Evacuate-Instance allowed due to component failure for nova_server-2703, host controller-1.

Two things...

First, if data ports are disabled on all hosts then there's no point in migrating or evacuating because it won't help anything.  It would be better to simply do nothing until there is at least one node that has a data port.

Second, if the original VM can still be running and talking to shared resources (like Cinder volumes) then it's not safe to evacuate the VM since that could result in filesystem corruption if you have two VMs accessing the same volume.

Hypervisors are brought down if data ports are disabled, and the recovery audit short-circuits and does not attempt any recovery actions if no hypervisors are found.

For the cinder stuff, the VM is in error state, but not powered-down, so it probably is still running.

This is a change in behavior. Previously, if 'force_reload_policy_dir' was False, then we would determine whether we should scan a directory for policy changes on a directory-by-directory basis. For example, if dir_a was updated but dir_b was not then we'd only scan dir_a for updates. With this change, we now scan all directories if a single one changes (so both dir_a and dir_b in this example). Was that intentional? If so, can you add a comment explaining why this is necessary for future reviewers.

Yes, if change was made in any policy directory or main policy file then all policy directories and main file are re-calculated from scratch.
We don't have separate rule sets for every policy folder, we only have the only rule set in RAM for all rule configs (self.rules)
So it's the only way to be consistent.
I gave a short example how current behavior is misleading:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.policy/+bug/1943584/comments/3

Comments in code will be added soon.

I must admit I'm struggling to follow the logic here. Why are we loading the policy file at 'self.policy_path' again? We already did this above starting on line 622. Could you add some comments explaining why you're doing this and what role the conditional plays?

"if force_reload_policy_dirs and existing_policy_dirs:"
Here we realize that some policy folders or main policy file were changed and we need to recalculate all rules from scratch, including a main policy file and all policy folders.
First we care about a main policy file. We look at "policy_file_rules_changed". If it's true then we know:
1. all rules were already reset here: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.policy/+/808957/7/oslo_policy/policy.py#622
2. rules from main policy file were already applied.

If "policy_file_rules_changed" is False, then we know that main policy file was not changed and rules were not reset and rules from main policy file were not applied on top of empty "self.rules" yet. So we reset rules and force to re-calculate rules in main policy file. And after that we apply rules from every policy directory.

Also we pass arguments for the function:  force reload=True (we re-calculate all files no matter they were changed or not), overwrite=False (we do not reset rules, we already made it when main policy file was re-calculated).

if rules in main policy file were not changed, then total rules in RAM are not reset and main policy file is NOT reloaded. So at this moment we have sum of rules from main policy file and directories from their previous state. 
Now policy_file_rules_changed == False.

Function "_load_policy_file" does not reset rules if a file was not changed, please see the function code.
If something *has* changed, or if we've insisted that everything be reloaded, we indicate that we'll reload the policy directories also
If a main policy file was changed or we insist to reload all rules from scratch then we insist to reload all policy directories.
Similarly, if any of the policy directories has changed (or more specifically, if any of the directory contents have changed), then we also indicate that we'll reload policy directories

The problem is that if "policy_file_rules_changed == False" then a main policy file was not reloaded and rules were not reset on line 622.
So we should force to reset all rules and re-calculate a main policy file.

Even if timestamps are the same in main policy file (main policy file was not changed) we cannot take rules from the main policy file and apply policy directories rules on top of main policy file rules.
There is no separate rule entity for main policy file rule and for policy directory rules. We only have "self.rules" which is sum of all rules already applied.

if 'self.overwrite' is set to False, then rules will not be reset and all new rules will be applied on top of "self.rules".
I doubt if an user uses Enforcer(overwrite=False).
By default overwrite == True in class "Enforcer" and in function "_load_policy_file".
But if an user uses Enforcer with self.overwrite=False, it's weird pattern and user's responsibility.

But - I agree, it does make things more complicated and if we're good just putting the entire file down early before the accounts exist then I'm on board with that.
Landing just for metadata change for release.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Discussed this internally with Felipe that:

if a driver does not support AA HA they should not be clustered, therefore their sub-charm should report stateless=False on OS releases where they don't support AA HA. The 'stateless' word is not appropriate because being stateless does not mean they can be clustered, as explained in the spec that introduced the 'cluster' config (referenced in LP: #1945239), which also explains why the aggregation of cinder-volume services should not be done using the 'host' config with the same value across all nodes.
